    • Analyze and Visualize Cheese Data with Shiny

    Analyze and Visualize Cheese Data with Shiny

    Analyze-and-Visualize-Cheese-Data-with-Shiny.Rmd

    Introduction

    This vignette demonstrates the usage of three functions designed for analyzing and visualizing cheese data: 1. Data cleaning: The clean_cheese_data() function is used for cleaning the raw cheese data. 2. Analysis functions: The analyze_fat_by_country() function provides analytical tools for summarizing and visualizing cheese characteristics. 3. Shiny app launcher: The launch_cheese_app() function launches an interactive Shiny app for a more in-depth exploration of the cheese data.

    # Load the functions (use relative paths)
source("/Users/wangshu/Desktop/assignment-4-packages-and-shiny-apps-shuwang0405/global.cheese.analysis/R/data_cleaning.R")
source("/Users/wangshu/Desktop/assignment-4-packages-and-shiny-apps-shuwang0405/global.cheese.analysis/R/analysis_functions.R")
source("/Users/wangshu/Desktop/assignment-4-packages-and-shiny-apps-shuwang0405/global.cheese.analysis/R/launch_app.R")


# Load necessary libraries
library(dplyr)

    Data Cleaning

    Example: Clean Raw Cheese Data

    The clean_cheese_data() function handles missing values, converts fat content to numeric format, and standardizes country names.

    # Load raw cheese data
cheese_raw <- read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2024/2024-06-04/cheeses.csv')
#> Rows: 1187 Columns: 19
#> ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
#> Delimiter: ","
#> chr (17): cheese, url, milk, country, region, family, type, fat_content, cal...
#> lgl  (2): vegetarian, vegan
#> 
#> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
#> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

# Clean the data using the custom function
cheese_data_clean <- clean_cheese_data(cheese_raw)
head(cheese_data_clean)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 19
#>   cheese     url   milk  country region family type  fat_content calcium_content
#>   <chr>      <chr> <chr> <chr>   <chr>  <chr>  <chr>       <dbl> <chr>          
#> 1 Abbaye de… http… cow   France  NA     NA     semi…          40 NA             
#> 2 Abbaye du… http… cow   France  Nord-… NA     semi…          50 NA             
#> 3 Abertam    http… sheep Czech … Karlo… NA     hard…          45 NA             
#> 4 Acorn      http… sheep United… Betha… NA     hard…          52 NA             
#> 5 Adelost    http… cow   Sweden  NA     Blue   semi…          50 NA             
#> 6 ADL Brick… http… cow   Canada  Princ… Chedd… semi…          12 NA             
#> # ℹ 10 more variables: texture <chr>, rind <chr>, color <chr>, flavor <chr>,
#> #   aroma <chr>, vegetarian <lgl>, vegan <lgl>, synonyms <chr>,
#> #   alt_spellings <chr>, producers <chr>

    Analyze Fat Content by Country

    The analyze_fat_by_country() function calculates the average fat content of cheese by country.

    # Calculate average fat content by country
avg_fat_by_country <- analyze_fat_by_country(cheese_data_clean)
print(head(avg_fat_by_country, 10))
#> # A tibble: 10 × 2
#>    country               avg_fat_content
#>    <chr>                           <dbl>
#>  1 United Kingdom                   52  
#>  2 Austria, Germany                 50  
#>  3 Croatia                          50  
#>  4 Hungary                          50  
#>  5 Lithuania                        50  
#>  6 England                          48.8
#>  7 Switzerland                      48.3
#>  8 United Kingdom, Wales            48  
#>  9 Germany                          47  
#> 10 Scotland                         46.5

    Launch the Shiny App

    The launch_cheese_app() function launches a Shiny app for interactive data exploration.

    # Launch the Shiny app (this command is not run in the vignette)
launch_cheese_app()
